title: Restoring Accountability to Policy-Influencing Positions Within the Federal Workforce

enrichment.summary: This executive order reinstates and modifies a previous policy that creates a special classification of federal employees in policy-influencing positions, called Schedule Policy/Career, to increase accountability. It enables easier dismissal of employees in these roles for failure to implement administration policies and revokes a prior order aimed at protecting certain workforce rules. The order emphasizes restoring presidential control and accountability within the federal civil service, especially among those shaping and executing policy.
potential_concerns: The reinstatement and modification of Schedule Policy/Career positions may lead to decreased job security and increased dismissals among federal employees in policy-influencing roles, raising concerns about politicization of the civil service (theme: schedule-f-political-appointments, civil-service-reform).

Removing previous protections that limited dismissals could undermine merit system principles, potentially discouraging federal employees from providing candid, nonpartisan advice, thereby affecting effective governance (theme: revocation-of-previous-executive-orders, federal-workforce-management).

Greater presidential control over policy-influencing positions might increase turnover and reduce institutional knowledge within the federal workforce, negatively impacting continuity in policy execution (theme: civil-service-reform, regulatory-reform-deregulation).
